awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Confirming and Characterizing Transiting Exoplanets around Bright Stars with Ultra-precise Ground-based Photometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Many extra-solar planets ("exoplanets") are discovered today by tracking precisely the light from the star they orbit. When the planet transits, or passes in front of, the star, a tiny bit of the star's light is blocked. This allows astronomers to determine many properties of the planet. The PI's team are pioneers in using an optical device called an Engineered Diffuser. This device significantly reduces sources of uncertainty in the light output of the star, especially the effect known as scintillation ("twinkling," in a layperson's term). They will use this technique to identify, confirm, and study planets down to Earth's size around bright stars. They will also use the technique to study the stars' magnetic fields by detecting spots analogous to sunspots on the surface of the stars. Undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral associate, will take part in the observations and data analysis. The collaborators will also incorporate the results into their teaching and public outreach at their institutions.

Ground-based observations are subject to a number of limitations in their precision due to the day-night cycle, atmospheric effects, scintillation, transparency variations, differential extinction, seeing, and telescope-guiding effects which typically prevents them from achieving the photometric precision of space-based missions. The larger field of view offered by small aperture telescopes enables bright comparison stars to be more readily found, however, the aforementioned challenges often prevent small telescopes from matching space-based photometric precision. Larger telescopes offer better averaging of scintillation. The group's implementation of diffuser-aided photometry from the ground provides an improvement in performance compared to de-focused small telescopes and they have demonstrated on-sky photometric performance that rivals that of space telescopes at a fraction of the cost.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Our project had 2 major, complementary goals:

 

Goal #1 of the project:  To leverage the unique observational capability provided by engineered diffusers and build upon our commissioning and pilot science observations, to conduct a comprehensive ground-based program to identify, confirm, and characterize candidate sub-Neptunian to Earth-size planets around bright stars. This is necessary to accurately define planetary demographics and to identify and characterize the individual planets most suitable for future atmospheric studies.

 

Goal #2 of the project:  To use exquisite diffuser-aided transit photometry to measure the positions and sizes of small-scale starspots on a select sample of transiting planet host stars. Since Sunspots are known to be the location of strong concentrations of magnetic fields on the Sun, individual starspots can be used as tracers of the underlying local magnetic fields on distant stars.  Diffuser-assisted light curves of select stars allow us to model their starspots and characterize their magnetic fields.

 

Our project was successful in both of these goals.  Through peer-reviewed journal publications, we characterized 21 substellar companions to nearby stars.  We also produced two peer-reviewed publications dedicated to characterizing starspots through exoplanet spot-crossing events, as well as exploring starspot effects in several of our publications characterizing exoplanets.  Throughout our efforts, we demonstrated the efficacy of diffuser-assisted differential photometry, and broadened its application in observational exoplanet science.

 

Broader Impacts

 

Our project had three top-level Broader Impacts goals:

 

  1. Widening the availability of engineered diffusers for precise differential photometry
  2. Training of undergraduate and graduate students in astronomical research
  3. Public communication of our research through the Habitable-zone Planet Finder (HPF) science blog

 

As for the Intellectual Merit objectives, we were successful in all of these goals.  We have distributed diffusers to users throughout the community and consulted on their usage.  Most notably, this resulted in the integration of an engineered diffuser on Las Cumbres Observatory's MuSCAT3 imager.  Graduate and undergraduate students at all institutions within our collaboration have been engaged in the research conducted for this project, including training on diffuser data collection and reduction.  Finally, the HPF science blog featured 8 articles describing research conducted through this project.
